skill.name: gget
skill.description: Fast CLI/Python queries to 20+ bioinformatics databases. Use for quick lookups: gene info, BLAST searches, AlphaFold structures, enrichment analysis. Best for interactive exploration, simple queries. For batch processing or advanced BLAST use biopython; for multi-database Python workflows use bioservices.
skill.summary: Fast CLI/Python queries to 20+ bioinformatics databases. Use for quick lookups: gene info, BLAST sea...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate bioinformatics tool. All 592 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES triggered by markdown documentation format. The analyzer misinterpreted markdown code block delimiters (backticks) as Ruby backtick execution, and flagged bioinformatics algorithm names as 'weak cryptographic algorithms'. No subprocess, os.system, or command injection patterns exist in the actual Python code.

content.user_title: Query genomic databases for gene and sequence analysis
content.value_statement: Quickly query 20+ bioinformatics databases including Ensembl, UniProt, and PDB. Retrieve gene information, perform BLAST searches, predict protein structures with AlphaFold, and run enrichment analysis. Runs as CLI tool or Python function.
actual_capabilities: Query gene information from Ensembl, UniProt, and NCBI databases
Perform BLAST and BLAT sequence similarity searches against standard databases
Retrieve protein structures from RCSB PDB and predict structures with AlphaFold
Run functional enrichment analysis against gene ontology and pathway databases
Fetch orthology and expression data across species from Bgee and ARCHS4
Access single-cell RNA-seq data from CZ CELLxGENE Discover Census
limitations: Process approximately 1000 Ensembl IDs at a time with gget info
BLAST searches limited to pre-formatted NCBI databases; custom databases require biopython
Some modules (AlphaFold, cellxgene, ELM) require one-time setup with large downloads

use_cases.title: Quick gene lookups
use_cases.description: Find gene metadata, sequences, and orthologs across species for research analysis.

use_cases.title: Sequence analysis
use_cases.description: Run BLAST searches, align sequences with MUSCLE, and predict protein structures.

use_cases.title: Expression and enrichment
use_cases.description: Analyze gene expression patterns and perform functional enrichment studies.

prompt_templates.title: Basic gene lookup
prompt_templates.prompt: Use gget to search for the {gene_name} gene in human and retrieve its Ensembl ID, description, and UniProt ID.

prompt_templates.title: Sequence retrieval
prompt_templates.prompt: Fetch the nucleotide and protein sequences for Ensembl ID {ensembl_id} using gget and save them to FASTA files.

prompt_templates.title: Structure prediction
prompt_templates.prompt: Use gget alphafold to predict the 3D structure of this protein sequence: {sequence}. Include AMBER relaxation for accuracy.

prompt_templates.title: Enrichment analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Run gget enrichr on gene list {gene_list} using the GO Biological Process database and return significant terms with p-values.

output_examples.input: Use gget to search for genes related to "GABA receptor" in human and get their detailed information.
output: Found 5 genes matching 'GABA receptor' in human:
â€¢ GABRA1 (ENSG00000022355) - Gamma-aminobotropic receptor subunit alpha-1
â€¢ GABRB3 (ENSG00000166206) - GABA-A receptor subunit beta-3
â€¢ GABRG2 (ENSG00000113303) - GABA-A receptor subunit gamma-2
All genes have UniProt IDs and are associated with 2-4 PDB structures each.

best_practices: Run gget setup for AlphaFold, cellxgene, ELM, and gpt modules before first use to download required dependencies.
Use --limit parameter to control result sizes when querying large databases for better performance.
Save results with -o flag for reproducibility and document database versions in research workflows.
anti_patterns: Do not process more than ~1000 Ensembl IDs in a single gget info call to avoid timeouts.
Avoid using case-sensitive gene symbols incorrectly in cellxgene queries (PAX7 vs Pax7).
Do not skip database version specification when reproducibility is important for published analysis.

faq.question: What databases does gget query?
faq.answer: gget accesses 20+ databases including Ensembl, UniProt, NCBI, RCSB PDB, ARCHS4, OpenTargets, and cBioPortal.

faq.question: Can gget run BLAST searches?
faq.answer: Yes, gget blast performs nucleotide and protein BLAST searches against NCBI databases including nt, nr, swissprot, and refseq.

faq.question: Does gget require installation?
faq.answer: Yes, install with uv pip install gget or pip install gget. Some modules like AlphaFold require additional setup.

faq.question: What output formats does gget support?
faq.answer: CLI returns JSON by default or CSV with --csv flag. Python returns DataFrames that can be saved as CSV, JSON, or FASTA.

faq.question: Can gget predict protein structures?
faq.answer: Yes, gget alphafold uses a simplified AlphaFold2 implementation to predict 3D protein structures from sequences.

faq.question: How is gget different from biopython?
faq.answer: gget provides unified CLI and Python access to pre-configured database queries. Use biopython for custom BLAST databases and advanced bioinformatics pipelines.
